{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3338464,"name":"karlf","username":"karlf","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/c0e974/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-20T16:07:45.838Z","cooked":"

We purchased a new RoboRIO 2 late last year (pre-season) with the intent of using it in this year’s robot. All of our motors are using CAN, so we normally don’t have any reason to use PWM. Our only exception is for LED strips. Last year we successfully used the PWM ports to drive a WS2812B LED strip. However, when we plugged it in to the RIO2 this year and added the code, they didn’t work. Further diagnostics revealed that it seems to be a PWM port issue. Our old RIO is showing the normal ~6V on the PWM ports and successfully lights the LEDs. The RIO2 is showing no power (or rather very, very low power) on all of the PWM ports.

Is there something that’s different with the PWM ports on the RIO2?

Since it’s a new RIO and we don’t normally use the PWMs, we try to keep them covered. So, I’m fairly confident we haven’t shorted out or over-powered any of them, but there is a possibility we have. If one was somehow shorted, would they all go bad?

Thanks in advance!
Karl Fleischmann - Mentor
Team 7491 Cyber Soldiers

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2024-03-20T16:07:45.838Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":76,"reads":119,"readers_count":118,"score":423.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":459455,"topic_slug":"roborio-2-pwm-has-no-power","display_username":"karlf","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/frc-1257-parallel-universe-2024-build-thread-open-alliance/447080/23","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"FRC 1257 Parallel Universe |2024 Build Thread | Open Alliance","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33059,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/roborio-2-pwm-has-no-power/459455/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3338478,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-20T16:16:21.683Z","cooked":"
karlf:

If one was somehow shorted, would they all go bad?

Yes, all PWM ports share a common 6V power supply rail. You should see a 6V fault indicator in the DS diagnostics tab if the rail voltage is low.

Our team has the same issue, we believe it was because our IR Break Beam Sensors drew more than the 6V provided by the ports and shorted them. We just moved the power for the sensors to a Mini Power Module instead. Most likely going to power our LEDs from it as well.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2024-03-20T18:50:45.936Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":82,"readers_count":81,"score":41.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":459455,"topic_slug":"roborio-2-pwm-has-no-power","display_username":"Ekansh Bansal","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.adafruit.com/product/2168","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"IR Break Beam Sensor with Premium Wire Header Ends - 5mm LEDs : ID 2168 : Adafruit Industries, Unique & fun DIY electronics and kits","clicks":4}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59452,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3349M"},"post_url":"/t/roborio-2-pwm-has-no-power/459455/3","custom_user_title":"3349M","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"thinking","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3338767,"name":"Domtech","username":"Domtech","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/domtech/{size}/138487_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-20T19:18:57.630Z","cooked":"

The break beam sensors are nothing more then a single LED and a photodiode, the current draw should be well below what the RIO is designed to provide.

From the spec sheet:

Also wouldn’t it be plugged into 5v from the DIO ports not 6V from the PWM ports?

Interesting, guess we were going about it wrong from the start. We have little experience with sensors from our previous team, and this is the first season our current team is competing. At the moment, the Mini Power Module is working well for us, but we will definitely keep this in mind for future reference. Thank you so much!

Ecoplayz:

We just moved the power for the sensors to a Mini Power Module instead

Ecoplayz:

At the moment, the Mini Power Module is working well for us

Wait… Now that I think more about it, How is this working? If you are actually powering those 5V sensors from 12V I would expect them to have an extremely reduced lifespan if they didn’t burn out instantly.

Yes, all PWM ports share a common 6V power supply rail. You should see a 6V fault indicator in the DS diagnostics tab if the rail voltage is low.

Thanks! We’ll check that and see.
